issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

fields.description:
After 2-3 days of nominal use and load the QA cloud is becoming unresponsive to API requests. There are about 15-20 instances running and not a great deal of churn on the cloud (maybe 2-3 instance launches per day). This event has happened 3 times in the last week since the upgrade to 4.1.

Once the condition hits it takes the CLC a very very long time to shut down (5-10 minutes). This last time I was able to get some heap dumps which I hope can help in triaging.
fields.summary: Cloud becomes unresponsive after a few days of regular use

comments.body:
The eucalyptus-cloud process not responding to SIGTERM is always and everywhere because of threads which are either: (1) deadlocked (then it never stops), (2) livelocked (sometimes stops, eventually, if the SIGTERM breaks the livelock), or (3) queued up.

Looking at a thread dump (SIGQUIT) after sending a SIGTERM would help with cases #1 and #2.

Looking at the state of the {{Threads}} pools to identify #3.  Note, though, that I have noticed thread queues, pools, etc. which are managed outside of {{Threads}} so this method is not comprehensive anymore.

There can be lots of causes for threads ending up in the described state, and identifying the offending threads is job 1 for systematically finding the root cause.  Of course, we might have the good fortune of just knowing where the problem is, then that is better :-)
Thread dump while this is happening.
I believe this most recent event occured at around 3:20 AM
!requests-log.png!

This call stack is not good:

{code}
"Eucalyptus.dns:EphemeralConfiguration:arn:euca:eucalyptus::dns:com.eucalyptus.cloud.ws.UDPHandler/.class java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor$Worker#180" prio=10 tid=0x00007f2c0c03c000 nid=0
x7138 waiting for monitor entry [0x00007f2b8f8b8000]

Infact, there are more signs pointing to log4j...

{code}
"OOB-148,g-19-12-33420" prio=10 tid=0x00007f2bd4024800 nid=0x120f waiting for monitor entry [0x00007f2ba1fdf000]
   java.lang.Thread.State: BLOCKED (on object monitor)

On this box i had setup rsyslog to ship off logs. This may be related if in fact log4j is locking up.

Ancient thread about log4j deadlock that is mayhaps related:
https://bz.apache.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=41214
I have disabled the remote syslogging for now. Will see if that has any effect.
After bringing the cloud up this last time, instances are taking a very long time to terminate and be launched.

[~decker]

That log4j issue doesn't look like a deadlock (yet) to me. Although it does look very similar, looking at the code it looks like 1.2.17 definitely has the 'fix' for the issue you linked to. Those two threads are pointing to this thread:

{code}
"Eucalyptus.dns:EphemeralConfiguration:arn:euca:eucalyptus::dns:com.eucalyptus.cloud.ws.UDPHandler/.class java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor$Worker#302" prio=10 tid=0x00007f2c0c118800 nid=0x71bb runnable [0x00007f2b87d3d000]
   java.lang.Thread.State: RUNNABLE
	at java.util.Arrays.copyOf(Arrays.java:2367)
	at java.lang.String.<init>(String.java:168)
	at java.lang.String.valueOf(String.java:2868)
	at java.lang.Thread.getName(Thread.java:1170)
	at org.apache.log4j.spi.LoggingEvent.getThreadName(LoggingEvent.java:387)
	at org.apache.log4j.AsyncAppender.append(AsyncAppender.java:155)
	at org.apache.log4j.AppenderSkeleton.doAppend(AppenderSkeleton.java:251)
	- locked <0x0000000785041f38> (a org.apache.log4j.AsyncAppender)
	at org.apache.log4j.helpers.AppenderAttachableImpl.appendLoopOnAppenders(AppenderAttachableImpl.java:66)
	at org.apache.log4j.Category.callAppenders(Category.java:206)
	- locked <0x0000000784e62770> (a com.eucalyptus.system.log.EucaLogger)
	at com.eucalyptus.system.log.EucaLogger.forcedLog(EucaLogger.java:37)
	at org.apache.log4j.Category.log(Category.java:856)
	at org.jboss.logging.Log4jLogger.doLog(Log4jLogger.java:42)
...
{code}

Which _shouldn't_ be blocked on anything as its just getting the thread name.

And I don't see similar behavior in the thread dump from 7:50, or am I missing something?

[~viglesias]
Next time this happens we should get thread dumps at some interval, like a thread dump @ 1 minute intervals, for 5-10 minutes. This can help piece together if a certain set of threads are taking a long time and causing the hang. 

I'm pulling down the heap dump, which will take a while.
Just happened again.

There are OutOfMemory errors in the startup log. Looking at the latest one from earlier today there are thousands of objects that look to be of type: DeferredPropertiesBootstrapper. 
[~viglesias] Can you get a database dump of eucalyptus_config so I can take a look. euca-describe-services seems to be 'clean' its showing everything as enabled... but I want to take a deeper look. 

Thanks,
-Steve

So looks like there is only once instance of com.eucalyptus.ws.DefferedPropertiesBootstrapper, but there are roughly 364,000,000 references to that object from approximately 864 instances of java.util.ArrayList. This is taking up 3.1GB of the heap:

!Suspects.png!

Looking at the objects view we see the number of parents that object has:

!ObjectsView.png!

And looking at the TreeView we have a couple of things, several ArrayLists with no parents, that all reference the DeferredPropertiesBootstrapper. Also there is one of note (that might be causing this?) com.google.com.collect.iterators. 

!TreeView.png!

Definitely looks like a leak.
java_pid20620.hprof, which was generated on Feb 27 shows the exact same memory behaviors, huge ArrayLists of references to DeferredPropertiesBootstrapper.

Splicing two tool screenshots together. First screenshot:
!PossibleSource.png!

The SynchronizedMultimap @ 0x78b5fab30 is the 'boostrappers' member of the ComponentBootstrapper class. We can see that in that map there is a key/value pair that contains a large ArrayList with the same DeferredPropertiesBootstrapper.

Looking with MAT: The object names/values are a little clearer:
!PossibleSource2.png!

The key is: com.eucalyptus.bootstrap.Bootstrap$Stage
Value is the array of objects.

What isn't pictured from the first image is that the associated component is a NodeController. At the moment I can't locate any information in the memory dump if it is a specific node controller or not.

Still digging, seem to be getting closer. The problem looks like it is somewhere in the ComponentBootstrapper code. 

-Steve

There are two things in the db:
eucalyptus_config.config_partition still references the deleted cluster: 'nested' 

In regards to the log message that [~ccassler] mentioned, that is still getting printed. That error is also related to the removal of the 'nested' cluster from the system.
{code}
id;sc_name;status;volume_name
00000000443efbce01445c97f8553786;nested;deleting;vol-66483E41
00000000443efbce01445c8fec9e3750;nested;deleting;vol-DB403FEB
{code}

The workaround to the problem should be the removal of the 'nested' row out of the eucalyptus_config.config_partition table. We should also be able to remove the two volume entries, although I need to double check with the storage team.

I'd like to try and reproduce the problem, what were the exact steps of the upgrade and cluster removal? Was the cluster removed prior to the upgrade or post upgrade?

Also the slowdown hasn't occurred again since last week right? As of right now eucalyptus-cloud is consuming about 1.3GB of RAM.

Thanks,
Steve

I took this code and wrote a small program to reproduce the issue, and it is trivial to do so. Making the function thread safe resolves the issue. In observing the output of my program there are various 'outcomes' to the error, one path leads to a memory leak and OOM. Another case can lead to the bootstrapper value being cleared altogether. 

Leak example:
{code}
Stage value length is: 1 Thread: pool-1-thread-7
Stage value length is: 1 Thread: pool-1-thread-2
Stage value length is: 1 Thread: pool-1-thread-4
Stage value length is: 1 Thread: pool-1-thread-5
Stage value length is: 1 Thread: pool-1-thread-3
Stage value length is: 1 Thread: pool-1-thread-6
Stage value length is: 1 Thread: pool-1-thread-8
Stage value length is: 1 Thread: pool-1-thread-1
Stage value length is: 1 Thread: pool-1-thread-10
Stage value length is: 2 Thread: pool-1-thread-9
{code}

Empty list example:
{code}
2015-03-13 15:27:14.096 Stage value length is: 1 Thread: pool-1-thread-6
2015-03-13 15:27:14.097 Stage value length is: 0 Thread: pool-1-thread-8
{code}

This is a timing issue, and it has been in the code for a while. It isn't clear what triggered the issue in the QA cloud, my best guess is that it has something to do with the removal of the 'nested' cluster from the environment. 

I'll fix this in 4.1.1.

-Steve

AWESOME job figuring out this one Steve!

On Fri, Mar 13, 2015 at 3:20 PM, Steven Graham (JIRA) <




-- 


*Tim Cramer - VP Engineering*
[image: Description: eucalyptus-150x16]

www.eucalyptus.com

+1 408-431-4711

Follow us on Twitter <http://twitter.com/#%21/eucalyptuscloud>

Like our Facebook Page

Keep up-to-date with us
<http://go.eucalyptus.com/Sign-Up-for-Cloud-Computing-News.html?Offer=Other&OfferDetails=Sign%20Up%20for%20Cloud%20Computing%20News&LeadSourceDetails=Eucalyptus%20Website&OfferURL=http%3A%2F%2Fgo.eucalyptus.com%2FSign-Up-for-Cloud-Computing-News.html>
<http://www.eucalyptus.com/>

I wanted to summarize this EUCA so that I bring in all the loose ends and wrap up this ticket.

*Overview*
 * The initial assessment that the thread dumps looked bad are a false positive on any of the issues involved
 ** The thread dump was only taken *once* which doesn't give us a valid set of snapshots of the system state
 ** The threads were not deadlocked. They are _blocked_ but that is a perfectly valid state. 
 ** Additional thread dumps taken when the event was occurring again, did not show log4j threads at all 
 ** The event occurred again _after_ [~viglesias] had removed the rsyslog logging configuration.
 ** The log4j fixes noted in the ancient thread,  are in the current version of log4j that we are using. 

 * java.util.NoSuchElementException: Failed to lookup ENABLED service of type Storage in partition Partition:name=nested
 ** This is a direct result of the VolumeDeleterTask trying to delete two volumes that are in the 'deleting' state for the old cluster 'nested'.
 ** These two volumes: {{vol-66483E41,vol-DB403FEB}} can be safely marked as 'deleted' in the DB and should resolve this error message. 

 * Memory Leak is the root cause of the issue
 ** As shown in updates to this ticket, the {{updateBootstrapDependencies()}} method  is not thread safe and leads to the memory leak(s).
 ** Two heap dumps confirm that the same memory footprint (leak) is at fault for the issue.

*Conclusion*
 * non thread safe method {{updateBootstrapDependencies()}} triggers several memory leaks and is the root cause of the unresponsive system.
 * There is not enough evidence that there is a log4j problem at this time. 

*Next Steps*
 * I will check in the memory leak fix into 4.1.1 next week. 
 * We can then turn back on the rsyslog features that were enabled on the system, this should resolve any issues. 
 * I can assist QA with marking the 2 volumes as 'deleted' in the DB (if needed)

Thanks
-Steve

[~sgraham] Can I get the correct Branch Name and commit hash? Did you commit and push this fix to your local branch? 
{code}

  maint-4.1
  master
[mmunn:/root/source/review/internal]git show

index 9394b1d..2700de0 160000
--- a/eucalyptus
+++ b/eucalyptus
@@ -1 +1 @@
-Subproject commit 9394b1d0e346934d743c6e6e0d2306b049d181f8
+Subproject commit 2700de086c6d5648559d9fa47c54723425346fe0
[mmunn:/root/source/review/internal]
{code}
[~sgraham] fix looks good, next please include the git hash as it makes finding the fix much easier.

I was able to trigger this condition on a different cloud pretty easily without the fix. With the fix I have not seen the lock up at all.

The cloud was also using rsyslogd and was doing quite a bit of logging at that with lots of instances/volumes/api requests. 

Thanks [~sgraham].
